zone.line: I looked around me and saw no object
that told me where I was; I had lost
myself, and in vain attempted to find
my path. I wandered on, and the
coming darkness made every trace
indistinct by which I might be
guided. At length I was v all was
veiled in the deep obscurity of black
est night; I became weary and
p knowing that my servant was
to sleep that night at the neigh-
bouring village, so that my absence
would alarm no one; and that I
was safe in this wild spot from every
intruder, I resolved to spend the
night where I was. Indeed I was
too weary to walk further: the air
was chill but I was careless of bodily
inconvenience, and I thought that I
was well inured to the weather during
my two years of solitude, when no change
of seasons prevented my perpetual
the plain,
